articles.headline: Home Insurance Is Clobbering Consumers. Yet It’s Barely Counted in Inflation.
articles.snippet: Skyrocketing premiums are hitting homeowners hard, but they barely factor into common price measures.
articles.abstract: Skyrocketing premiums are hitting homeowners hard, but they barely factor into common price measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: Holly Meyer Lucas estimates that as many as 30 of the 100 houses her real estate team sold in and around Jupiter, Fla., last year were put on the market because their owners could no longer keep up with skyrocketing home insurance.

articles.headline: Pentagon Opens Ammunition Factory to Keep Arms Flowing to Ukraine
articles.snippet: A plant still under construction in Mesquite, Texas, will soon turn out 30,000 artillery shells each month, roughly doubling current U.S. output.
articles.abstract: A plant still under construction in Mesquite, Texas, will soon turn out 30,000 artillery shells each month, roughly doubling current U.S. output.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a warehouse off Lyndon B. Johnson Freeway in an industrial area outside Dallas, the future of American military ammunition production is coming online.
articles.byline: By John Ismay and Desiree Rios

articles.headline: Alito Refuses Calls for Recusal Over Display of Provocative Flags
articles.snippet: “My wife is fond of flying flags,” the justice wrote in a letter to members of Congress who had demanded he step down from two cases related to the Jan. 6 attack. “I am not.”
articles.abstract: “My wife is fond of flying flags,” the justice wrote in a letter to members of Congress who had demanded he step down from two cases related to the Jan. 6 attack. “I am not.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. declined on Wednesday to recuse himself from two cases arising from the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol after reports that flags displayed outside his houses appeared to support the “Stop the Steal” movement.

articles.headline: Americans Raced to Get Their Families Out of Gaza. Then the Border Slammed Shut.
articles.snippet: The closure this month of the Rafah border crossing into Egypt, the only way out for civilians, has thrown an already complicated system into disarray.
articles.abstract: The closure this month of the Rafah border crossing into Egypt, the only way out for civilians, has thrown an already complicated system into disarray.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ghada Redwan, a 48-year-old pharmacist in Houston, has been trying to get her parents out of Gaza for months. Their bags, packed and ready to go, have been sitting by their door in Rafah, the city where Israel is now conducting a military offensive.

articles.headline: Mexicans Are on the Verge of Electing Their First Female President
articles.snippet: Claudia Sheinbaum is the front-runner in Mexico’s presidential race, but she is wrestling with the image that she could be a pawn of the current president.
articles.abstract: Claudia Sheinbaum is the front-runner in Mexico’s presidential race, but she is wrestling with the image that she could be a pawn of the current president.
articles.lead_paragraph: Claudia Sheinbaum’s list of accolades is long: She has a Ph.D. and a shared Nobel Peace Prize and was the first woman elected to lead Mexico City, her nation’s capital and one of the largest cities in the Western Hemisphere.

articles.headline: Why Are People So Down About the Economy? Theories Abound.
articles.snippet: Things look strong on paper, but many Americans remain unconvinced. We asked economic officials, the woman who coined “vibecession” and Charlamagne Tha God what they think is happening.
articles.abstract: Things look strong on paper, but many Americans remain unconvinced. We asked economic officials, the woman who coined “vibecession” and Charlamagne Tha God what they think is happening.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy has been an enigma over the past few years. The job market is booming, and consumers are still spending, which is usually a sign of optimism. But if you ask Americans, many will tell you that they feel bad about the economy and are unhappy about President Biden’s economic record.

articles.headline: Europe Banned Russia’s RT Network. Its Content Is Still Spreading.
articles.snippet: A study found that hundreds of sites, many without obvious Kremlin links, copied Russian propaganda and spread it to unsuspecting audiences ahead of the E.U. election.
articles.abstract: A study found that hundreds of sites, many without obvious Kremlin links, copied Russian propaganda and spread it to unsuspecting audiences ahead of the E.U. election.
articles.lead_paragraph: The website calling itself Man Stuff News caters to a certain sensibility, with categories like “Backyard Grilling,” “TV Shows for Guys” and “Beard Grooming.” A recent article headlined “Tips for Dads During Labor” offered this nugget of advice: “Just remember to spend some time together before deciding whether or not to give birth.”
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Steven Lee Myers
